turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Christ, Tripp. How did you know?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Call it a hunch.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Naturally you have copies.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I have an alternate version of the first chapter.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: You'll be all right then. Look at Carlyle, when he lost his luggage.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That was MacCaulay.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Or Hemingway, when Hadley lost all those stories.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He was never able to reproduce them.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Bad examples. Look, Tripp, I don't want to depreciate the loss here, but perhaps -- in a sense -- this --  is for the best.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Kind of a sign, you're saying.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: In a sense.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't think so. In my experience, signs are usually a lot more subtle.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: The jacket, Tripp. We need the jacket.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh, right. Oola. About that jacket...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Came to my senses.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Ah. Well. Congratulations. Meanwhile, what is James supposed to do? Pray for Walter Gaskell to come to his?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Walter Gaskell isn't going to send James Leer to jail, Crabs. I know that.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Do you know he won't expel him?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No. But I don't think that matters.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: That's very enlightened, Professor. It's comforting to know that America's children have you for a teacher.

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: Me? What can I do?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Gee, I don't know, Crabs...  Improvise. You're good at that.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You peeked, didn't you?

turns.speaker: CRABTREE
turns.text: I peeked.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: How are you -- is it Joe?

turns.speaker: GOATEE KID
turns.text: Jeff. Sorry. I didn't even know this was your house until about an hour ago.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Don't sweat it. Well. 'Night, Jeff.

turns.speaker: GOATEE KID
turns.text: Oh, Professor Tripp? You know, last semester, what I said that time in office hours -- I hope there's no hard feelings.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: GOATEE KID
turns.text: I mean, I was breaking up with this girl at the time and my car was ail fucked up and -- well -- I was pretty bent in general.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's cool, Jeff. Really.

turns.speaker: GOATEE KID
turns.text: I just want you to know that's why I dropped your class and said all that shit about the university stealing my money and you being a pseudo- Faulknerian nobody.

turns.speaker: GOATEE KID
turns.text: I'll be... somewhere else.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hey, Jeff. If you're really interested in discussing that business with the tango, try the guy at the end of the hall.

turns.speaker: VERNON HARDAPPLE
turns.text: You driving this car?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: VERNON HARDAPPLE
turns.text: This 1966 maroon Ford Galaxie 500. You driving this car?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's mine.

turns.speaker: VERNON HARDAPPLE
turns.text: Bullshit. It's mine, motherfucker.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You must be mistaken.

turns.speaker: VERNON HARDAPPLE
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I passed out.

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I've been doing that a lot lately.

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: So I hear. You've also been smoking a lot of marijuana, I understand.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Do you think that's why I've been having these...  ...spells?

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: How long have you been having them?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: The last month maybe.

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: How long have you been smoking marijuana?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Spiro T. Agnew was vice president, I believe.

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: That's probably not the problem, then. What about your lifestyle. Any major changes recently?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I've been trying to finish a book...

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: And your wife left you.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Is that in my chart?

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: I spoke with the woman who saved your life. You're lucky she came along when she did.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: You need to see a doctor, Mr. Tripp. An internist. And I think you really ought to consider seeing a therapist, as well.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: She told you about...

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: Her dog, yes.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Actually, it was her husband's dog...

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: Look, Mr. Tripp. You have a drug problem, all right? On top of that, you have a bite on your ankle that is severely infected. We pumped you with antibiotics so you'll be fine, but another day or two and you might have lost the foot. As for your spells. I'm guessing they're a result of the anxiety you've been experiencing lately.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: They're anxiety attacks? That's a little disappointing.

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: Better luck next time.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: So is my friend... is Sara still here?

turns.speaker: GREENHUT
turns.text: No. There's no one here.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I have to see her. As soon as possible.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Vernon.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Move away, cupcake. He's got a gun.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Who's got a gun?

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: You've got a gun, motherfucker. Drop it!

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Relax, Vernon...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Not true. You're the only Vernon I know. Actually, I'm wrong. I once knew a Vernon Peabody at Penguin U.K.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Shut up.  Cupcake. Please. Inside.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's just a souvenir. They don't even make the caps anymore.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Bullshit. I know a gun when I see one. And that's a gun.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No, really...

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Who the hell is that?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: A Manhattan book editor murdering a Mormon girl's clutch.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Let me get this straight. All that paper that went into the river. That was the only copy?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: 'Fraid so.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: And you're saying it's some kind of sign? What the fuck's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hey, Vernon. Can I ask you a question?

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Shoot.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Boy or girl?

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: As long as it looks like her, I don't care. You know what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Right. Well, thanks. For the lift.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: No sweat. Only do me a favor?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: VERNON
turns.text: Stop calling me Vernon.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: Grady, it's Sara. Thank God you're there. You won't believe what's happened.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Could you hold on a minute, honey?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sara? Hi. It's Grady.

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: Where are you, Grady? An elevator?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm in Kinship. Listen, Sara, there's some things we need to talk about...

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: You're in Kinship?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yes. But that's not why I called...

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: With Emily?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What? No. There's no one here. I'm just... just...

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: Just what? Doing a little dusting?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: ...reconcile with Emily.

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: Are you there to not reconcile with her?

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: Goodbye, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No. Sara, you don't understand...

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: Trust me, I understand. I just want to say something to you, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yea?

turns.speaker: SARA'S VOICE
turns.text: How you choose to live your own life is your business. But you be careful with that boy, Grady. With James. He belongs to somebody else.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It was my mother's. She won it in a penny arcade in Baltimore when she was in Catholic school.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's very convincing.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It used to shoot these little paper caps, but they don't make them anymore. The caps.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's just... for good luck. Some people carry rabbits' feet...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: ...You carry firearms.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Are you and Hannah seeing each other, James?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: No! What gave you that idea?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Relax, James. I'm not her father. I just rent her a room.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: She likes old movies like I do, that's all.  Besides, she doesn't really know me. She thinks she does, but she doesn't. Maybe it's because she's Mormon and I'm Catholic.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Maybe it's because she's beautiful and she knows it and try as she might to not let that screw her up, it's inevitable that it will in some way.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You're not like my other teachers, Professor Tripp.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You're not like my other students, James. So what was the movie you two saw?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Huh? Oh. Son of Fury. With Tyrone Power and Frances Farmer.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: She went crazy, Frances Farmer.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: So did Gene Tierney. She's in it too.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sounds like a good one.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's not bad.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Listen, James, about this afternoon. In workshop. I'm sorry. I think I let things get a bit out of control.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: They really hated it. I think they hated it more than any of the other ones.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It doesn't matter. It only took me an hour to write.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Really? That's remarkable.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I have trouble sleeping. While I'm lying in bed I figure them out. The stories.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You cold, James?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: A little.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: So what are you doing out here?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's colder in there.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Actually, I saw the greenhouse. So I thought... I thought I'd come out here and take a look at it. You don't see one of those every day. It looks like heaven...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Heaven?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I saw a movie once. Part of it took place in heaven. Everyone wore white and lived in crystal houses. Like that. At least that's the way I remember it...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James.  Don't leave just yet. There's something I think you ought to see.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'll miss my bus.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: This is worth it.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Is that really it?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That's really it.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: The one she wore on her wedding day?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: So I'm told.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: They're glass. The buttons.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Like the lady herself.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's feels unreal, like butterfly wings or... something. It must've cost Dr. Gaskell a lot.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I guess. Walter never tells Sara the truth about how much he pays for these things.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You're really good friends with the Chancellor, aren't you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Pretty good. I'm friends with Dr. Gaskell, too.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I guess you must be, if you know the combination to his closet and he doesn't mind your being here in their bedroom like this.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm sorry. Professor Tripp. Maybe it's seeing that jacket that belonged to her. It just looks... really lonely. Hanging there. In a closet. Maybe I'm just a little sad.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Maybe. I'm feeling a little sad myself tonight.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You mean, with your wife leaving you and all?  Hannah mentioned something about it. About a note.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yes. Well. It's complicated, James. I think we should go now.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Shit, James. You shot Dr. Gaskell's dog.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I had to. Didn't I?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Couldn't you've just pulled him off me?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: No! He was crazy. I didn't -- he looked -- I thought --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Okay, okay. Take it easy. Don't freak out on me.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Do you have a mirror? It's the best way to see if someone's breathing.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He's dead, James. Believe me, I know a dead dog when I see one.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Professor Tripp? Can I ask you a question?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yea, James.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: What are we going to do with...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't know. I'm still trying to figure out how to tell the Chancellor I murdered her husband's dog.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Trust me, James, when the family pet's been assassinated, the owner doesn't want to hear one of her students was the triggerman.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Does she want to hear it was one of her professors?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I've got tenure.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: That's a big trunk. It fits a tuba, a suitcase, a dead dog, and a garment bag almost perfectly.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That's just what they used to say in the ads. Come on, Crabtree, I know you're holding...

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Whose tuba is that anyway?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Miss Sloviak's.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Can I ask you something about her?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: She is. Ah. Here we go...

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Oh. So. Is -- is your friend Crabtree -- is he -- gay?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Most of the time he is, James. Some of the time he isn't. Now what do we have here?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Looks like... our old friend Mr. Codeine. That should take the pinch out of my ankle.  Have one.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: No thanks. I'm fine without them.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Right. That's why you were standing in the Chancellor's back yard twirling that little cap gun of yours tonight. You're fine, all right, you're fit as a fucking fiddle.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: This is so embarrassing! You guys had to carry me out.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Is he all right?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Mmhmmm... knap... sap...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What's he saying?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Shit. He must've left it back at Thaw. In the auditorium.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Mmrrmmm... KNAP SAP!

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You're welcome.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm okay. I just lost my balance.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I put you on the floor.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I thought you might -- I don't know -- swallow your tongue or something.  I guess you really miss her, huh?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Huh? Oh, no. This isn't Emily's. I just write in it.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I guess there's probably a story behind that.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: There is, but it's not that interesting.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Want me to get that?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: He didn't give his name.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: The guy on the phone.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What'd he say?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: He wanted to know if a Grady Tripp lived here and drove a dark maroon 1966 Ford Galaxie 500 with black interior.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What'd you tell him?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Good, James. If the Zodiac killer calls, be sure to mention the back door pops open with a couple hard shakes to the right.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I thought maybe you'd won a radio contest or something. Is that single- spaced?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Afraid so.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: That's a big book you're writing.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I think it's sort of writing itself at this point.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Wow, Hannah always swore you were working, but --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: But... ?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Nothing, it's just that, well, it's been awhile since Arsonist's Daughter, and some people -- some of the kids in workshop -- thought maybe you were...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Washed up?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Blocked.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Ah. I don't believe in writer's block.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Professor Tripp?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hm.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: How did I get here last night?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No one seems to know where you live, James. Hannah thought you'd like my couch.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: And... and before that. Did I do anything? Anything bad?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well, James, you did shoot the Head of the English Department's dog and steal his most prized piece of memorabilia.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well done, James.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I got kicked out. Well, not exactly kicked out. I was asked to leave.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I guess there's probably a story behind that.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: There is, but it's not that interesting.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: So where have you been staying?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: The bus station.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's not so bad. I know the night janitor. And there's a broken locker I can put my stuff.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: But James. I mean... How long?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: A couple weeks. That's why... that's why I had the gun. For protection.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Jesus, James, you should've told someone.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't know...  Me.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Isn't this...?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hm.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I can't help myself. I don't know what's the matter with me.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Shit, James, you're hungover. What do you think's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: She seemed to take it pretty well.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yeah, well, actually...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Don't be proud, James. We're in Sewickley Heights. We could find you a nice golf course to barf on.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I've got a thing about, places like this. I know what those houses are like. I know what the people are like.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Your aunt?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Humboldt County?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Maybe...

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's my father. He gets it from his doctor.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Glaucoma?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Colon cancer.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Jesus, James. Wow.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's a bit of a scandal. My parents live in a small town.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Where's that?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Carvel.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Carvel? Where's Carvel?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Outside Scranton.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I never heard of it.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's a hellhole. Three motels and a mannequin factory. My dad worked there for thirty-five years.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Your father worked in a mannequin factory?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Seitz Plastics. That's where he met my mom. She was a fry cook in the cafeteria. Before that, she'd been a dancer.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What kind of dancer?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Whatever kind they wanted her to be.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James Leer, are you telling me your mother was a stripper?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm telling you what I was told by my uncle. And he should know. He ran half a dozen men's clubs in Baltimore before he skipped town on a bad debt.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Didn't you say your Mom went to Catholic school?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: When we fall, we fall hard.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Amazing.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I thought you were the guy who didn't like to lose control of his emotions.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Maybe I just needed the moment to present itself.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: This is so nice. It's like where Andy Hardy would live. What's it called again?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Kinship.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Kinship. And what's here?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Unless I miss my bet... my wife.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: The one that left you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That's right. That one.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Someone jumped on your car with their butt...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: How can you tell?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You can see the outline of a butt.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Want one. They're incredible. Incredible.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Smoke the rest of that joint, James, and you can start on the box.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Maybe she didn't come here.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: She came here. We'll just wait. In the meantime, I need you to shimmy through.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Relax. Emily hasn't carried a house key since she was twelve years old. And your hips are as slim as hers.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's not that. It just reminded me of -- you know -- of what's in the car. In the trunk.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh. Right. Well, let's try not to think about that.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It feels really... good... here.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I know. It's the house you want to wake up in on Christmas morning.  Make yourself at home. I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I just wanted a little sip.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I just wanted a little sip? Tell me, James, exactly what point was it that you turned into Serpent Boy?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Probably about the time you gave me the codeine pills last night.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Jesus...  Look, James, you appear to possess -- like many an aspiring writer before you, by the way -- a rather ardent affinity for the stuff of which dreams are made. However, I think it's best if, for the moment at least  ...we abstain.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You're mad at me, aren't you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You're mad because I shot your girlfriend's dog.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It wasn't her dog. It's her husband's --  Who said anything about girlfriend?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Okay, James, I wish you hadn't shot my girlfriend's dog. Even though Poe and I weren't exactly what you'd call simpatico, that's no reason for him to take two in the chest. Still, the fact remains that I'm the one who took you up into the Chancellor's bedroom. I'm the one who has to take the blame. I don't know what the hell I was thinking.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Sure you do. You were thinking: 'That's no cap gun in that kid's overcoat.' You were thinking 'I can't let that kid get on the bus alone -- he might never get on the bus again.' You were thinking: 'I've got to find a way to distract this kid.' So you did. It was -- in its way -- a noble act.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Thanks for the halo, James, but I've never done that much thinking ahead in my life -- ever.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: So, why did you take me up there?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't know, James. I don't know why I do half the things I do. Who does?  Why do you wear that coat?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's warm.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James, fall semester, first day of class, it was 95 degrees and you were wearing the coat.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That's why they all give you such a hard time in workshop.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Because of my coat?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Because you act like a goddamn spook all the time. Not to mention the fact that every last one of them is jealous of you.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Jealous? Of me?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Not you. Your talent.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You're lying.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: The hell I am.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Yes you are. My stuff stinks. I know it. You said so yourself.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I never said that.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Yes you did. Last night. To your friend Crabtree. "Is he any good?" he said. And you said: "Not yet he isn't." I heard you myself.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I didn't mean it that way.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's okay, Professor Tripp. Carrie, Howard, the others -- they're right. My stories are annoying. They go on and on and on, and the longer they go on the more annoying they become, until finally you just want to grab something heavy and --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Shut up, James. You're annoying. Carrie and Howard don't know what the fuck they're talking about, okay? The entire class combined -- including the lovely Hannah Green -- has about one tenth of one percent the talent you have, okay?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: But, last night...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Who cares what I said last night, James I -- I was drunk, I was stoned. I'd been bitten by a dog. My wife had left me. How 'bout cutting me some slack?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: And don't be so goddamn sensitive. Who cares what anybody thinks anyway? You want to be a good writer? You want to be a great writer? Then stop giving a damn what other people think. Most of them haven't thought in years.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Let me spell it out for you, James. Books don't mean anything. Not to anybody. Not anymore.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Arsonist's Daughter meant something.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: You coming?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: In a minute. Get us a table.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Want a bite?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: That's why you're having them. Your spells.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Spells? Jesus, James, you make it sound like we're in a Tennessee Williams play. I don't have spells.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: What would you call them then?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't know... 'Episodes.'

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: It's because you don't eat.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I eat.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: When nobody's looking.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You just worry about yourself, James. Okay?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Nowhere. You just sit here and... eat.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm not going with them.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James. Listen. Things -- things are a little weird with me right now and I -- well --I have enough blame to shoulder these days without having to take the blame if something bad happened to you. And if you hang around me long enough, something bad is going to happen, trust me. That's why I need you to go home. Understand?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm not going, with them.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James, like it or not, they're your parents.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Parents? They're not my parents. They're my grandparents. My parents are dead.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I remember that. Five or six years ago.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Six. Their plane went down right outside Scranton.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Near Carvel?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm sorry about all that. I just -- I don't like to talk about my family. They treat me like a freak.  She makes me sleep in the basement of my own house. It's mine. My parents left it to me.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Get out of here.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: That's why she hates me. That's why she makes me sleep in the basement.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: In the crawl space, with the rats and the casks of Amontillado. Come on. Up.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Can I -- I mean -- do you mind -- if I wear this again. Professor Tripp?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Ah, wear whatever you want.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: And we both thank you for that, but we're... we're... fine.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm fine, right. Fit as a fucking fiddle.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Does she mean -- does she know about... her dog?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's Walter's dog and yes, she does know. But let's spare her the details. Come on, your shoes are in the hail.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Don't worry, James, I'll figure something out.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: I'm not worried. You're not worried, are you. Professor Tripp?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm a little worried, James.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Don't be. I don't care if they expel me. I probably should be expelled.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well, let's see if we can keep that from happening.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Professor Tripp...?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yes, James.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Even if I end up going to jail....

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yes, Hannah?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I think maybe we're missing the point. It seems to me James' strength as a writer is that he doesn't take us by the hand. He treats us like adults. He respects us enough to forget us. That takes... courage.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Thanks for that. He all right?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I think so... What about you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Me? Sure. Why?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Just checking.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He's going with me. You take Crabtree. And his friend. All right?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Ail right. By the way, his friend...?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: The answer's yes. I think. Yes. I don't know. Where are they exactly?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James. This is my editor, Terry Crabtree.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: James'll know about George Sanders.
